Bayesian colocalisation analysis for two quantitative traits, measured on the same individuals

Source: R/colocqq.R
coloc.qq.Rd

This function calculates posterior probabilities of different causal variant configurations under the assumption of a single causal variant for each trait.

coloc.qq(N, VY1, VY2, corY, MAF, LD, p1 = 1e-04, p2 = 1e-04, p12 = 1e-05,
  W1 = 0.15^2 * VY1, W2 = 0.15^2 * VY2)

Arguments

N

number of samples
VY1

variance of trait 1
VY2

variance of trait 2
corY

cor(Y1,Y2)
MAF

minor allele frequency of the variants, named vector
LD

matrix giving correlation between SNPs. NB - this is r, not rsquared! Expect a mix of positive and negative values. This should be estimated from reference data.
p1

prior probability a SNP is associated with trait 1, default 1e-4
p2

prior probability a SNP is associated with trait 2, default 1e-4
p12

prior probability a SNP is associated with both traits, default 1e-5
W1

the effect size of any variant for trait 1 under the assumption it is causal is assumed to follow a normal with mean 0 and variance W1
W2

as above, for trait 2

Value

a list, with main entry "results" a vector giving the number of SNPs analysed, and the posterior probabilities of H0 (no causal variant), H1 (causal variant for trait 1 only), H2 (causal variant for trait 2 only), H3 (two distinct causal variants) and H4 (one common causal variant)

Details

Unlike coloc.abf, this specifically requires coefficients and their standard errors - ie p values and MAF are not enough, because the direction of effect matters

Contents

  • Arguments
  • Value
  • Details
